text: TITLE CARD: the early 15th century A scorched battlefield littered with the dead and dying. Hundreds of tangled bodies strewn across the field. Horse them. So thick and twisted they carpet the sodden earth. deformed mass. Bloody, black and brown. A WARRIOR walks the field. Broad shouldered. A cape of fu leather and chain mail. He walks laboured. A body squirms at his feet. He stops. He raises his worn and, as if planting a flag, he thrusts the metal down int dying man’s back. The body arches stiff and then goes lim He continues on in this fashion, casually roaming the des bodies and giving those still moving their silence. Aroun across the field, others pore over the bodies, pilfering valuables or taking the not-fatally wounded hostage. The warrior turns. His scarred face, young but lined. Sad soulful eyes. Despite being a clear victor here, he looks displeased, agitated, dark. This is SIR HENRY ‘HOTSPUR’ PERCY. He continues his macab walk. He stops at the body of a man wheezing his last shallow b into the dirt. With his filthy, bloody boot, Hotspur heav man onto his back and regards him with what looks for a m like pity. He then plunges his sword into the man’s chest Walk. Stab. Walk. Stab. He watches an injured man stand shakily and walk - fall - his feet again and walk. The man trips and keeps moving. Hotspur walks beside him for a few steps. Falling into st watches the limping man’s action, studies him curiously. from a deep gash across his face makes it impossible for see from either eye. Other injuries too.

Where go you, my friend? The man turns to the sound. Scared, he tries to continue. HOTSPUR (CONT’D) You're hobbling in the wrong direction. That wind you feel is blowing from England. Scotland is that way.  The limping man, uncertain, turns and follows the wind. Hotspur turns and walks away. Stab.

Royal Court, London. Hotspur, cleaned from the battlefiel walks the hall with his father, the EARL OF NORTHUMBERLAN beside him. Northumberland appears wary. Hotspur strides. They are met by sentries and the Chief Justice SIR WILLIA GASCOIGNE.
My Lords Percy.
We have come to see the King.
I'm afraid His Majesty is engaged with other concerns. Is he expecting your visit?

I should hope he is. We are but the men who have spilled blood in his name. I should hope that he expects our visit with enthusiasm. William notes Hotspur’s hostility and disappears through antechamber to a room beyond. Hotspur’s agitation is a source of unease for Northumberl an unease which cannot be addressed openly before the sil helmeted sentries standing watch.
My son. Be calm. Hotspur stares, boiling, in the direction of the door bey which the King is engaged with his other matters.

Hotspur and Northumberland sit at one end of a long dinin table. They are quiet. Hotspur’s agitation boils. A door opens. KING HENRY IV hobbles in. Royal courtiers f William, the EARL OF WESTMORLAND, LORD SCROPE OF MASHAM, EARL OF CAMBRIDGE, SIR THOMAS GREY, the EARL OF DORSET am them.

My lords, I am most sorry for making you wait. I know you have travelled far and from great travail. The King extends his signet for the lords to kiss. Northumberland does so obligingly, eyes lowered. Hotspur kisses the ring while looking Henry coldly in the eye.

I pray you will know this time of civil unrest consumes me day and night. As the King and his courtiers take their seats, servants food to the table. Others present jugs and bowls of water the men to rinse their hands.
I understand battle with the rebel Scots was hard fought. Is this true? Hotspur stares. Northumberland fills the awkward space.
It was, my liege. We lost some three hundred men. They bow their heads as the King says a Latin blessing.
Benedic nos Démine et haec Tia déna quae de Tia largitdte stmus sumptiri. Per Christum Déminum néstrum. Amen.
Amen. The men eat, the King as heartily as his frailty will all Hotspur doesn’t eat. Henry looks to him.
And how many prisoners were taken?
Some two hundred, my liege.
Good Hotspur, you led the charge. Were any prisoners of note taken?
Many.
Are they in train?
No. Henry eats, ignoring the insolence.
And why is that? Why have they not been brought directly to me as is their designation?
Why will you not pay cousin Mortimer’s ransom?
You’1l need to speak up, my boy. I’m an old man. My ears are filled with hair.
Cousin Mortimer is held by the rebels of Wales. Why do you refuse to pay his ransom?
I refuse to pay Mortimer’s ransom because I refuse to believe Mortimer a prisoner. I rather believe Mortimer to be a traitor. Henry lets this sit. He eats. Hotspur boils. Moments pass

Your victory over the Scots was a most heroic one, heroic because improbable. Our most recent loss to the Welsh, however, should not have been suffered. Our strength should have had it staved. And I must conclude only that it was suffered with Mortimer’s help, that Mortimer has joined the Welsh rebels, that he has betrayed England and that far from being a prisoner, your cousin is now an enemy of mine and, therefore, of yours.  5. Henry examines his chicken wing. Hotspur stares. The othe try not to be noticed.
Do you agree with my précis, good Hotspur?
No.
My son.
I believe yours to be the ramblings of a crazy old demon.
Harry. Please. Stop this.
Let him speak. I wish to hear him.
My liege -

Yours are the ramblings of an old man so saturated with malice and mistrust that he no longer knows up from down, who can no longer see beyond the walls of his own monstrous schloss. Henry stops eating. He pays Hotspur his full attention, a inviting Hotspur to continue. Hotspur, emboldened, does s HOTSPUR (CONT’D) My family has served you. My father, my uncle. We aided you in your ascension. And still we fight for you. Cousin Mortimer has fought for you - hard and for many years. And yet while you now slobber over that chicken’s wing, he shivers in a western prison awaiting mutilation at the hands of Welsh witches.
My liege, you must forgive my son. He needs rest. We come only to advocate for your help in securing Mortimer’s release.

All that we have done for you we have done for the good of England, but I fear now that we have made a terrible mistake. I fear the battles we have fought have been fought only to indulge your hateful madness. Our lands are now more riven with war than ever before. You have rebellion stewing in all corners. The Scots are not finished. The Welsh have only just begun. And for what? Why do you think this might be, old man? Who do you imagine might be to blame for this? All are stunned silent. Henry watches Hotspur strangely a impassively for a protracted moment.
My liege...

They say chickens can’t fly, but I’ve seen one eke enough wing flap to clear a fence. And then it’s free!... But then so too are the foxes. Henry continues his dull stare at Hotspur. Hotspur boils, Henry’s gleeful crypticism is intimidating.

You are right, young Percy. I owe you much. I owe your family still more. You have fought nobly for me. You carry wounds fresh for me to see. And your grievances too - they have been heard. But if the Scottish traitors you have taken prisoner are not brought to me as speedily as they might travel, I will hang you by your fucking neck. Henry watches him another moment.
Has this been heard, Percy? Hotspur fumes. He heaves his chair from the table and str the door. Northumberland rises meekly and bows. Scrope looks to him, catching his eye.
Please forgive us, Your Majesty. They scurry after Hotspur. Henry watches them leave. The courtiers remain silent, unable to read the King’s dispos
What a venomous boy. He’ll betray me now. I’m sure of it. Henry returns his attention to his chicken wing.
But if only he were my son.

PRINCE ‘HAL‘ HENRY (25) lies face down and naked on a bed a spartan single-room apartment. He’s sprawled and snorin Daylight punches through the window. Sounds of people and animals from the street below. The sound of keys in the door. It opens. An unkempt SIR J FALSTAFF (45) and BEALE (26) enter. Falstaff’s arm bleeds Falstaff shuts the door behind him loudly. Hal wakes with start.
What is this?
Falstaff has injured his self.
How did you get in?
The door was ajar.
It wasn’t.
It was. It was ajar.
It was not ajar.
How else might I gain entry? Are you accusing me of having cut myself a secret key?
Yes.
Falstaff has injured his self, Hal.
Why have you come here? What happened to you? Hal’s head is throbbing. Beale rifles through Hal’s stuff

I think it best a man of your standing not be burdened with those particulars. I think it best the circumstances in which the injury was accrued be left entirely mysterious. Beale has found a bottle of liquor.
(to Hal) Will you perform the small repairs?
No.
Your Highness. This task requires expertise. Should you not assist, I fear our friendship may come to a foul end right here on your floor.
Hal stirs honey in a pot. Beale pours wine over the gash Falstaff’s arm.
There’s a fresh coin in this for you.
I don’t want your coin. I will require your undiminished loyalty and devotion from here til Megiddo.
You have that already. You’re a soft negotiator. Hal puts the honey pot down and goes to the fireplace. He an iron rod from the fire. Beale trickles more booze.
You're wasting good wine.
I’m keeping it clean. Hal sits beside Falstaff. He wipes the wound with a strip linen. He then presses the red hot poker right onto it. F screams a scream that quickly turns to maniacal laughter.

Hal, Falstaff and Beale walk the street in a mangy part o London. Butchers’ stalls, garbage and mud. Fires and smok Dogs, pigs and filthy kids. Two men in clean cloaks step out of a dark doorway and fo Another two men appear from an alley and step in front of their mouths and noses covered by handkerchiefs.
Prince Henry. Falstaff and Beale are immediately on edge. They reach discreetly inside their coats for concealed weapons.
Who are you?
We come from the royal court. We wish to speak with you privately.
For what?
Please, sire. Privately.
Privately in the middle of Eastcheap? Shall I make a quick up and down to request a mass covering of ears?  10.
(ignoring Falstaff) Please, sire. Hal registers the look of earnest intent on the cloaked m face. He leads him away into a darkened alcove.
What is this?

Your father, His Majesty King - Hal pulls the kerchief from the man’s face, forcing him t breathe the fetid air. CLOAKED MAN (CONT’D) Your father, His Majesty King Henry, is ill. He requests your presence. Hal pauses momentarily, processing this mention of his fa
For what?
Your presence has been requested.
I suggest you return to the palace directly and tell him his request was wholly ignored.
I have been instructed to deliver the request with great urgency.
Then you might tell him your urgency was also wholly ignored. Hal steps past the man, leading Falstaff and Beale away.
A dingy tavern. Falstaff sits with others, among them Bea a drunk Hal.
Remember. Remember that as we speak there are two Popes. Two! One in Rome. One in France. (MORE )
They both claim to be the Lord’s voice here on earth. They can not both be. Why would a good Lord allow his kingdom to be so puzzled? He wouldn't, is that question's answer.
Which then is the true Pope?

I say not one or the other. I say the very fact of their quarrel makes them both snakes. And so, if our holy Roman fathers can not convey to us a true voice of authority, why should we assume that those snakes beneath them speak with any authority? The whole house is writhing with snakes -
Stop this now.
Why now?
I says stop.
Are you afraid Thomas might come for you in the night? Don’t be afraid of my ideas. They’re only ideas.
You sit before me now and tell me you no believe in the power of the one true God.

I do not. I do believe in the one true God. How dare you suggest otherwise. I do not believe that our Archbishop of Canterbury speaks for him. I would say our Archbishop Thomas Arundel only claims to speak for him.
To what end?  12.
Clearly to his own damned end.
You best bite your tongue in the company you keep. You’1ll have yourself necked.
(to Hal) You would have me necked? Hal smiles.

(to the drinker) I would say your devotion to the Archbishop - if it is devotion and not a slickly ruse to warm the mood of this company I keep - I would say it has me a more true believer in the one God than you.
Bite your tongue or I will neck you myself.
Bite my tongue? Why on this earth would I bite my own tongue?
Your word in this air is a poison.

Oh. My voice riles you. Maybe then better you should bite your own ears off. (starts laughing at the thought of it) Bite your own ears off! And maybe after you should kick yourself in your own balls! The drinker stands as if to confront Falstaff. Hal laughs From across the room, the tavern’s hostess HOOPER yells -
Stop now. Falstaff meanwhile is attempting to bite his own ears off And then as the drinker takes a step closer, Falstaff spr up and pins him against a wall, a dagger to his throat.  13.

Now now. Settle, my petal. You have a little brutish feeling in your belly. I see there be only one course to straighten this dispute... (beat, cold stare) You and I will cockfight... (releases the drinker, his tone lightens instantly) Hal, my knee is queer. You must be my cock.

A space has been cleared on the floor to stage the cockfi The ‘cocks’ are Hal and the drinker, crouched on haunches facing off. Beale stands behind Hal holding a horizontal sword six inches over his head. Another man stands behind drinker, holding a stick six inches over his.

Rules are plain. You topple over, you lose. You rise your head to the level, you lose. Those are the rules. Un, deux, trois. The fight is on. Hal and the drinker waddle towards each other, swiping and grabbing. They tussle, retreat. Tussle retreat. Onlookers yelp support. And then Hal grabs the drinker by his knee and topples him over. Onlookers howl. Falstaff raises his arms in the air.
The Lord hath spoken! Hal lies on his back, laughing.
Hal is drunk. He kisses a young woman on the bed. They la
Your Highness. Hal stops laughing. WOMAN (CONT’D) Your Highness. Hal covers her mouth. He is suddenly dark and distant.  14.
Stop. She is taken by surprise, intimidated.
Stop. Hal takes his hand away. She seems uneasy. He kisses her. woman has gone quiet.
Hal snoring. The woman sleeps beside him. Then the sound key in the door - Falstaff enters. He opens the curtain, stirring the woman unforced chivalry, he coaxes her from bed. Hal doesn’t st
My lady. It’s time to leave. He gathers her clothes. She wakes groggily.
That’s good, my dear. Jump up. The day has begun.
Why?
Shhh. The day has begun. Look. Out there. It’s well underway. You might miss it. Disoriented, the woman lifts herself. Falstaff holds her
That's the spirit. Lift your arms. She lifts her arms. Falstaff pulls the shirt down over he
I’m sorry to interrupt your slumber. He ushers her out of the room and closes the door behind places a cup of ale beside Hal and sits.
What are you doing? Hal speaks muffled, groggy, face smudged into the pillow.  15.
Can you hear me? Hal grunts.
You must get that door fixed.
What is it?
Visit with your father.
Go away.

If your father is indeed enough gravely ill to request your presence, then you must visit with him - it should be better to regret having done so than it would to have not. No matter your feelings for him. If your father is ill, you must visit with him. And - let me add - I say it not out of concern for our king’s well being, more for fear of the drunken soak to which you be likely to succumb should you fail to heed his call and he were to die without you having squared your ledger... I fear it would be soak enough to put even me to shame. Hal stares at Falstaff, lucid and penetrating, with his o not smudged into the pillow. Falstaff watches Hal a momen
Do it. If nothing else I ever suggest. Falstaff rises and exits. Hal percolates Falstaff's advic
Hal at the palace gates. Without exchange with the guards granted entry. All watch him with cold interest if not di  16.

Hal walks the hall under escort. As he approaches the antechamber he crosses paths with Grey and Cambridge on t way into the great hall. Grey eyes him with contempt. Cambridge looks at him cautiously, searching. William approaches Hal with something more like compassio genuflects subtly.
My lord. Your father expects you.
He shouldn’t. William observes Hal’s state of dishevelment.

King Henry is in his chair, visibly weak, presiding over sitting of parliament. The full court plus THE ARCHBISHOP CANTERBURY and clerical attendants are there. THOMAS OF LANCASTER, the King’s 18 year-old son, Hal’s yo brother, is there too. The Archbishop is addressing the king. He’s bumptious, bu nervous, and has a lisp.
Never. Never would I dare doubt Your Majesty’s piety, however I would remind you of the service we -
Archbishop, I would have thought our lord above would want us all to share in his bounty.

My liege, while I see the strain your treasury is under, I can not help but wonder if the canker of Lollardy be somehow at the root of this suggestion, that I - or rather the church - be burdened with a tax to relieve problems that are not of the church's making.
Your Highness.  17. The King looks up. Others turn also as Hal steps into the
Henry, Prince of Wales.
My son. Come to me. The Archbishop appears put out. He regards Hal with deris Hal crosses the room. He bows before his father, taking i his frailty. Henry takes in his son’s slovenliness.
Come closer. Hal takes a step closer. Henry watches him a moment.
I feel my life is nearing its natural end and yet still even I must appear of ruder health than you. Hal doesn’t respond. He continues looking his father in t
The time has come for me to consider the issue of my succession. You will not be king. Hal remains fixed. A barely concealed smirk on the face o
While you are my eldest son, for reasons that must be evident to you, that are on display for all here to see and smell, you will not inherit this crown.
Nor have I sought it.
That privilege and responsibility will instead fall to your brother Thomas. Thomas straightens, postures regally. It doesn’t suit him  18.

As you may be aware - to whatever degree you are aware of the world outside your own - I will assume you are aware that the kingdom is at war with itself. Matters as grave as these require leadership committed to their resolution and you - of this I am sure - you can not provide that commitment. Thomas, however, can. He is soft, but he is eager and he will lead my army against the newly treasonous Percy Hotspur. Hal looks at Thomas who has trouble meeting Hal’s eyes.

I will assume this news comes to you as neither surprise nor disappointment. I do however see it as my duty as King and as father to say it to you directly. Hal walks to Thomas. Thomas raises his head, holds Hal’s eyes.
How do you feel, brother?
Strong.
When do you fight?
I set off tomorrow. We fight by week’s end.
You need not fight. These feuds need not be yours. Hal takes Thomas’s face in his hand. Thomas leans his hea away and tries to stare at Hal. He is young and afraid.
I have said what you were summonsed to hear. Leave us now. Hal turns to his father, one last cold look, then leaves.  19.
Slow-motion: Falstaff is drunk, dancing in women’s clothi owning the room with his sweaty heft. Other drinkers laug Hal sits in the corner, oblivious and darkly contemplativ
A foggy field. Men in armour, horses, an air of trepidati Thomas is helped into his breastplate by an AMROURER. He’ nervous. He raises his arm as a strap is tightened. A CAP waits nearby.
(pained) Is it not too tight?
It has been made to the measurements I was given, sire.
May be you were given the wrong ones. It feels tight. I can barely turn.

It is to be worn tight, sire. Thomas steps away like he’s trying on new shoes. He seems awkward in his heavy suit, overwhelmed by it. He walks am men nearby. He smiles wanly. The men regard him with uncertainty. THOMAS’S CAPTAIN My lord, we must meet with your marshals. As the sun rises, the day will unfold. We must complete our preparations.
Of course.
Thomas enters the circle of seated men awaiting him. They their heads, but clearly doubt his skill and experience a worry about their own fate as a consequence.  20.
Lord Dorset, are your men ready for the day?
They are, sire.

Very good. (awkward beat) Tell me of your preparations. - and then a commotion from beyond the tents. Hal approaches slowly on horseback. A lone muscular figur A hush descends. To most here, Hal is an almost mythical the renegade son of their tyrannical king. He dismounts. He walks to Thomas. The crowd parts for him looks sharp, determined, steely.
Why are you here?
I will not allow this havoc to transpire. I have come to see it stopped.
This is my battle. You have no place here.
If I have my way there will be no battle. Hal turns to a HERALD nearby.
You. Come here.
You have no place here.

(to herald) Go to the rebel camp and deliver this message to Percy Hotspur. Tell him that Prince Henry challenges him to settle today’s score man on man. He and I. We fight in our armies’ places.  21.
I do not need you to fight my battles.
This battle is not yours. The herald hasn't moved, confused. Hal steps towards him.
Why have you not moved? Go! The herald scurries away. Dorset rises from the circle.
Who do you think you are?
I am nobody to you. As you are nobody to me. As Hal walks away, he watches the herald’s horse gallop a the field toward the rebel camp.
Hotspur stands. Northumberland sits. Scrope is there, hav defected from the King’s inner circle.
I will fight him. I will defeat him.
That you surely would, my son.
I will defeat him and we can leave this field whole and victorious.

That thrill of victory you so foresee would be short lived, for there is little chance that the King Henry would allow us walk free from this field. He would have us forever marked as traitors and we would spend the rest of our days awaiting his recrimination.
The offer has been made.
The Prince Henry speaks not for his father. Of this I am certain. You have started something, we have started something much larger here, and we must see it properly concluded.
You're eager to fight, my son. And you will. And we shall fight alongside you. We will burn them. We will burn Henry’s reign to the ground.
Hal is fitting himself with armour. He does so solemnly a meticulously. These may be his last moments alive. Thomas approaches him, furious.
It is unconscionable that you should seek to commandeer this moment of mine. This moment belongs to me.
This is not a battle you should be compelled to fight. These troubles are not of your making.
This is not for you to decide! This is not your place!
You do not know war, Thomas.
I do know war.

You do not. You may have skirted its perimeter, but you have not been inside it such as that which brews here on this field. And this here is not a place any sane or good man should aspire to know. Hal looks at Thomas, hoping he can see his sincere concer  23.

You have been recruited to our father’s madness, to wars that need not be fought. When I turned my back on him, on my birthright, I was turning my back on this field. These men are not our enemies, but our father has made them thus.
Why then are you here? You so disapprove of our cause, and yet still you find it necessary to upstage me?
I do this not to steal your thunder, brother. I do it to save your life.
These are not your decisions to make! Westmorland approaches. John turns, agitated.
Pardon me, my lords.
What is it?
Our herald is returned from the rebel camp. They have refused Prince Henry's offer. Thomas is stunned silent.
A line of two thousand men and horses - a battle-ready ar across the field, the thin line of Hotspur’s force is vis Thomas strides to Dorset and other officers. All is quiet
You should address the men, my lord - as is customary.
Of course.  24. Thomas looks around at the mass of men before him. They w him. He clears his throat.

Men. This day shall be a glorious one. It shall be a day that will live on in our memories for many years to come. Beat. Thomas looks nervously at the men staring back him, cold, distrustful. His pause is awkward, long. He continu weakly.
Battles such as this one are the pillars upon which a man’s life is built. Thomas stops. A murmuring from the men. Dorset leans in close.
You must speak up, sire. The men are having difficulty hearing you. Thomas is rattled, embarrassed. He steels himself and the loudly, yelling uncomfortably -

I know that many of you doubt me. I know many of you think me unworthy of your respect. But I promise you that today, from this moment, I will do everything in my power to make myself worthy of your respect. Awkward silence. The men wait for more. None comes.

Rebel preparations. Hotspur is now in formidable knight’s armour, elaborate and fearsome. He seems troubled. He don his helmet and mounts his horse, also decked in intimidat armour. Together they look powerfully murderous. Hotspur looks around the camp a moment, breathing deep be his visor. He then spurs his horse hard and gallops away across the field towards the English army. Startled attendants call after him.  25.
Thomas stands weak before his men.
Loke! There! All turn to see Hotspur’s lone, sharp approach across the Hotspur rides steadily towards Thomas’s army. As he nears slows, then stops close to the line. He removes his helme
Where is Henry? I have come to fight him, in our armies’ stead. Thomas steps forward, distressed and angry.
No. His offer was refused. We are ready.
The offer has been reconsidered. I will fight Henry. The outcome of that fight shall stand for the larger battle forestalled. It will be done. Hotspur dismounts his horse.
I said no. It will not be done. Hotspur walks closer.
Why is the little dog barking? Where be the big dog? Hal steps forward, helmet under his arm, sword by his sid
It will be done.
No!

If this here might prevent the death of countless of your men then you should wish it be done. You should wish it be done!  26. Thomas can feel the heavy stare of men who would rather n die, many of whom are themselves unsure of this battle’s Hal watches him a moment, then steps further towards Hots
And here I am with the whoring fool.
This fight need not be had, Percy. My father will soon be dead, and your grievances will die with him.

Don’t be afraid of our small contest, little Hal. I promise to finish it quickly. Hotspur dons his helmet. Hal watches him. Hal dons his own helmet. He stands firm, raises his sword Hotspur advances, calmly. Hal circles him. HOTSPUR (CONT’D) Your father is plague to England. Hal charges forward, swinging his sword. Hotspur blocks and deflects him easily. Hal stumbles. Hotspur stands calm and cocksure as Hal regathers. HOTSPUR (CONT’D) Come for me, big dog. Hal attacks again, this time steadier, more sure-footed. They trade blows. Hotspur is a powerful and battle-fit wa Hal seems more troubled by the contest, struggling to kee feet and trade blows. They fight, separate and circle each other. Despite his ascendency, Hotspur seems surprised by the fi puts up. He expected the win to be easier. He concentrate Northumberland and Scrope have arrived on horseback from rebel camp. They watch the fight. Another vicious exchange. The men break. They watch each other, catching breath. They circle one another.  21 27. HOTSPUR (CONT’D) Come for me again, dog. Hal raises his sword and stands firm and waits. Hotspur f coldly on him, then charges. The exchange is brutal. Hal his sword. He stands vulnerable. He pulls his dagger from scabbard. Hotspur laughs from behind his visor, then charges again. Hal ducks, spins. Hotspur trips and falls. Hal wheels aro thrusts his dagger straight through Hotspur’s throat. Hotspur is killed. Hal stands over him, heaving for breat The massed English army bearing witness stand silent, shocked, relieved, confused - certainly they didn’t want die, but many felt a greater allegiance to Hotspur than t did the family they were to fight for today. Hal pulls off his helmet. He tosses it on the dirt. He be lifts Hotspur’s helmet off. He contemplates Hotspur’s lif face. He seems saddened by it. Hal carries Hotspur’s helmet over to Thomas. All watch, silent. He drops the helmet at Thomas’s feet.
Some day this will be your head, dropped at the feet of a man who might otherwise have been your brother. Walk away from this field.

After you have stolen its prized scalp? This is what shall be spoken of tomorrow. This field was mine, it was to mark my dominion. Instead now it marks only this head. This fucking head. Thomas kicks Hotspur’s helmet like a football and walks a through the crowd.
Falstaff is asleep in bed snoring. A knock at the door. T opens - it’s hostess Hooper.
Go away.  22 23 28.
You might wish to see to your otherwise well appointed friend. He seems to have taken a pitiful turn.
Falstaff steps into the dark, quiet street to find Beale to rouse Hal who lies drunk and sick against a wall.
Hal's up-chucked again. Falstaff crouches before Hal. Beale steps away.
Hello, friend. What’s this foul mess you’ve chosen to lie in?
The tavern has emptied. Hal sits against a wall with a si bucket. Falstaff sits beside him, staring ahead.

Battle is ugly, brother. Many times have I seen men in your state. I’ve been in it many times over myself. For all our rejoice of courage and valour, nothing stains the soul more indelibly than killing. Never have I felt more vile than standing victorious on a battlefield... The thrill of victory fades quickly. What lingers long after is always ugly. Nothingness... Ugly. Falstaff sits remembering war. He shudders, shakes it off
Never again, I say.
Stop. Stop talking, old man. Falstaff smiles and pats Hal on the shoulder.
I will never stop talking, Hal. Falstaff stands and heads for the stairs.  29.
Hal is asleep on the floor. A gloved hand shakes his shou
My lord. Hal wakes. William stands over him, accompanied by a guar
What business?
It is a matter of great urgency.
You should hurry along then.
Please, my lord. Hal sits up. It’s a struggle. His head is throbbing.
Your father, my lord. He is gravely ill.
That hook has lost its worm. Hal massages his temples. William addresses his guard.
Wait for me outside. The guard exits. William sits on a bench beside Hal.
England needs a king.

Hal with Falstaff, William, Dorset, Scrope and Westmorlan They sit by a fire under a canopy slung from a tent.
